data.title: Penny Mordaunt interview: The woman in the hot seat
data.meta_description: She’s the first female defence secretary, a minister who doubles as a Royal Navy reservist and one of the most popular MPs in the House of Commons. She’s a natural mediator who finds the routine circus of political point-scoring tiresome. Had she run for the leadership, Penny Mordaunt could well hav
data.text:
She’s the first female defence secretary, a minister who doubles as a Royal Navy reservist and one of the most popular MPs in the House of Commons. She’s a natural mediator who finds the routine circus of political point-scoring tiresome. Had she run for the leadership, Penny Mordaunt could well have been our next prime minister. Instead the staunch Brexiteer decided, after much agonising, not to run and then surprised everyone by throwing in her lot with Jeremy Hunt.

So why the cold feet? In the end it all came down to timing. As the leadership race kicked off, she was at a defence conference in Singapore. By the time she returned, there were 13 candidates already in the running. Perhaps more importantly, she had
